GUI Synchronization Functions

SiSyncSendQuery

SpwReturnValue SiSyncSendQuery( SiHdl hdl )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 


Example
SiSyncSendQuery ( m_hdl );

Description
SiSyncSendQuery sends a sync query to the driver. The driver responds with a query packet if the configuration for the app has syncing enabled.  Normally the driver initiates the synching procedure with the application when the driver loads a configuration file that contains APP_CONTROLS_BUTTONS = TRUE.  If at anytime the application wants to initiate or reinitiate the synching procedure, it can call SiSyncSendQuery to the driver.  If the configuration file in use for the application does not contain APP_CONTROLS_BUTTONS = TRUE, all attempts to synchronize will be ignored.

 

SiSyncGetVersion

SpwReturnValue SiSyncGetVersion( SiHdl hdl, SPWuint32 *pmajor, SPWuint32 *pminor )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

pmajor 

(w/o) 

pointer to the major version of the sync interface 

pminor 

(w/o) 

pointer to the minor version of the sync interface 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

one or more the the pointers is invalid 


Example
SiSyncGetVersion( m_hdl, &major, &minor );

Description
SiSyncGetVersion retrieves the version of the sync interface in major.minor format.

 

SiSyncGetNumberOfFunctions

SpwReturnValue SiSyncGetNumberOfFunctions( SiHdl hdl, SPWuint32 *pnumberOfFunctions )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

pnumberOfFunctions 

(w/o) 

address of the number of functions buffer 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument 


Example
SiSyncGetNumberOfFunctions( m_hdl, &numberOfFunctions );

Description
SiSyncGetNumberOfFunctions returns the number of functions in the driver's current configuration for the application.

 

SiSyncGetFunction

SpwReturnValue SiSyncGetFunction( SiHdl hdl, SPWuint32 index, SPWint32 *pabsoluteFunctionIndex, WCHAR name[], SPWuint32 *pmaxNameLen )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

index

(r/o) 

the index for the function to be retrieved (1-n) 

pabsoluteFunctionIndex 

(w/o) 

the invariant function number (only for nonvarying functions)

name 

(w/o) 

the name of the function 

pmaxNameLen 

(r/w) 

the number of characters in name.  Will be set to required amount if too short, and set to retrieved amount if long enough. 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument 

SI_NOT_ENOUGH_MEMORY 

name is too small for the function name 


Example

for ( int i=0; i<numberOfFunctions; i++)
    SiSyncGetFunction( m_hdl, i+1, &functionList[i].absoluteFunctionIndex, functionList[i].name, &maxNameLen );

Description
SiSyncGetFunction returns the name of function number "index" and the absolute/immutable function number at the index. If the function is a macro, the absoluteFunctionNumber is negative. Macros can not be counted on to exist from config to config.  If *pmaxNameLen is too small, SI_NOT_ENOUGH_MEMORY is returned and *pmaxNameLen is set to the required length.

 

SiSyncGetButtonAssignment

SpwReturnValue SiSyncGetButtonAssignment( SiHdl hdl, SPWuint32 buttonNumber, SPWint32 *passignedFunctionIndex )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

buttonNumber 

(r/o) 

the number of the button to retrieve (1-n) 

passignedFunctionIndex 

(w/o) 

the function index that is assigned to this button 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument 


Example

for ( int i=0; i<numberOfButtons; i++)
    SiSyncGetButtonAssignment( m_hdl, i+1, &button[i].assignedFunctionIndex);

Description
SiSyncGetButtonAssignment returns the function index that is assigned to a button.

 

SiSyncSetButtonAssignment

SpwReturnValue SiSyncSetButtonAssignment( SiHdl hdl, SPWuint32 buttonNumber, SPWint32 assignedFunctionIndex )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

buttonNumber 

(r/o) 

the button to change

assignedFunctionIndex 

(r/o) 

the function that is to be assigned to this button
>0:  the button is to trigger an internal function (1-n)
  0:  the button event is to be passed straight thru
 -1:  the button is to be unassigned (does nothing)
 -2:  the button assignment is to be returned to the config's default value


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument 


Example
SiSyncSetButtonAssignment( m_hdl, 1, button[0].assignedFunctionIndex );

Description
SiSyncSetButtonAssignment assigns a new function to a button.

 

SiSyncSetButtonAssignmentAbsolute

SpwReturnValue SiSyncSetButtonAssignmentAbsolute( SiHdl hdl, SPWuint32 buttonNumber, SPWint32 absoluteFunctionNumber )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

buttonNumber 

(r/o) 

the button to change

absoluteFunctionNumber 

(r/o) 

the absoluteFunction that is to be assigned to this button
 >0:  the button is to trigger an internal function (1-n)
   0:  the button event is to be passed straight thru
 <0:  the button is to be unassigned (does nothing) 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument 


Example
SiSyncSetButtonAssignmentAbsolute( m_hdl, 1, absoluteFunctionList[0].absoluteFunctionNumber );

Description
SiSyncSetButtonAssignmentAbsolute assigns a function to a button using the absolute, never changing function number.  The function indices (1-numberOfFunctions) used to retrieve the function names (SiSyncGetFunction) are in the order that they are listed in the config file and are valid only while that config file is loaded.  If an application wants to store these functions between configs it may find that a different config is loaded the next time the application is run, and therefore some of the functions will not be there.  For example, macros can never be relied on being in the config because the user can create and delete them at will.  Some functions, though, are guaranteed to always be available.  In fact, they are always available to an application even if they aren't listed in the config file (e.g., ESC_KEY).  These absolute function indices are returned by SiSyncGetFunction. If the application wants to use these indices to set a button assignment, it uses SiSyncSetButtonAssignmentAbsolute.  Calls to SiSyncButtonAssignment and SiSyncButtonAssignmentAbsolute can be interleaved.

 

SiSyncSetButtonName

enum SpwRetVal SiSyncSetButtonName( SiHdl hdl, SPWuint32 buttonNumber, WCHAR name[] )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

buttonNumber 

(r/o) 

the button number to change (1-n) 

name 

(r/o) 

the new name for the "pass-thru" function for this button 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument


Example
SiSyncSetButtonName( m_hdl, 1, L"Open File..." );

Description
SiSyncSetButtonName function changes the name for the default (pass-thru) function for a button.  This is the string shown in the GUI and on the 3D mouse display when the button is set to pass the event straight thru to the application.

 

SiSyncGetAxisLabel

SpwReturnValue SiSyncGetAxisLabel( SiHdl hdl, SPWuint32 axisNumber, WCHAR name[], SPWuint32 *pmaxNameLen )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

axisNumber 

(r/o) 

the axis number (1-6) 

name 

(w/o) 

the buffer to write the axis label to

pmaxNameLen 

(r/w) 

the number of characters that can be written to name.  If too small, it is updated with the correct length.  If large enough, it contains the number of characters written. 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument 

SI_NOT_ENOUGH_MEMORY

if *pmaxNameLen is too small for the name 


Example
SiSyncGetAxisLabel( m_hdl, 1, TxName, &TxNameLen );

Description
SiSyncGetAxisLabel retrieves the label on a specific axis that is displayed in the 3DxWare GUI.  If *pmaxNameLen is too small for the label, SI_NOT_ENOUGH_MEMORY is returned and *pmaxNameLen is updated with the required length (in WCHARs).

SiSyncSetAxisLabel

SpwReturnValue SiSyncSetAxisLabel( SiHdl hdl, SPWuint32 axisNumber, WCHAR name[] )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

axisNumber 

(r/o) 

the axisNumber (1-6) to change 

name 

(r/o) 

the new axis label 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument 


Example
SiSyncSetAxisLabel( m_hdl, 1, L"Pan View Horizontal" );

Description
SiSyncSetAxisLabel changes the label displayed for an axis in the GUI.

 

SiSyncGetOrientation

SpwReturnValue SiSyncGetOrientation( SiHdl hdl, SPWint32 axes[6] )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

axes 

(w/o) 

the orientation of the six axes currently used by the driver 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument 


Example
SiSyncGetOrientation( m_hdl, axes );

Description
SiSyncGetOrientation returns the orientation of all 6 axes currently in use by the driver.  This allows an application to retrieve, then rearrange the axes with SiSyncSetOrientation.

 

SiSyncSetOrientation

SpwReturnValue SiSyncSetOrientation( SiHdl hdl, SPWint32 axes[6] )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

axes 

(r/o) 

the new orientation for the axes 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument 


Example
SiSyncSetOrientation( m_hdl, axes );

Description
SiSyncSetOrientation allows an application to rearrange the 6 device axes in anyway.  Each axis can be inverted or swapped with another axis.  This might be used by an application that wants Scale to be along a different direction than specified in the default config file for the application.  It is preferable to leave the driver at the default orientation and do the rearranging inside the application. 

 

SiSyncGetFilter

SpwReturnValue SiSyncGetFilter( SiHdl hdl, SiSyncFilter i, SiSyncFilterValue *pv )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

i 

(r/o) 

the filter to retrieve 

pv 

(w/o) 

the current setting of the filter 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument 


Example
SiSyncGetFilter( m_hdl, SI_SYNC_FILTER_TRANSLATIONS, &v );

Description
SiSyncGetFilter returns the setting of any of the filters set in the GUI.  The SiSyncFilter type enumerates the possible values.

 

SiSyncSetFilter

SpwReturnValue SiSyncSetFilter( SiHdl hdl, SiSyncFilter i, SiSyncFilterValue v )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

i 

(r/o) 

the filter to set 

v 

(r/o) 

the new filter state 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument 


Example
SiSyncSetFilter( m_hdl, SI_SYNC_FILTER_TRANSLATIONS, SI_SYNC_FILTER_OFF );

Description
SiyncSetFilter changes the state of one of the Degree of Freedom filters in the driver.  The SiSyncFilter type enumerates the possible filters that can be set.

 

SiSyncGetAxesState

SpwReturnValue SiSyncGetAxesState( SiHdl hdl, SiSyncAxesState *pa )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

pa 

(w/o) 

the buffer for the axes state


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument


Example
SiSyncGetAxesState( m_hdl, &a );

Description
SiSyncGetAxesState retrieves the state (on/off) of each of the six axes from the driver.  Each axis can be individually toggled in the driver's GUI.

 

SiSyncSetAxesState

SpwReturnValue SiSyncSetAxesState( SiHdl hdl, SiSyncAxesState a )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

a 

(r/o) 

the new state of each of the 6 axes 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument


Example
a.state = SI_SYNC_AXES_STATE_TX | SI_SYNC_AXES_STATE_TY;
SiSyncSetAxesState( m_hdl, a );

Description
SiSetAxesState turns on/off each of the axes in the driver.  If off, the driver zeroes out the value for that axis before sending it to the application.

 

SiSyncSetInfoLine

SpwReturnValue SiSyncSetInfoLine( SiHdl hdl, SPWint32 duration, WCHAR text[] )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

duration 

(r/o) 

the duration (in milliseconds) that the text is to be displayed on the 3D mouse integrated display (LCD).  <0 indicates to replace it "permanently" (until some other process or the driver replaces it "permanently").

text 

(r/o) 

the text to display on the LCD infoline


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument


Example
SiSyncSetInfoLine( m_hdl, 1500, L"Camera Roll Disabled" );

Description
SiSyncSetInfoLine replaces the text in the InfoLine (top line) of the 3D mouse display (LCD). If duration is >=0 it is replaced for a specific number of milliseconds, the reverts back to whatever it said before.  If duration is <0 it is replaced "permanently" until some other process replaces it "permanently" .

 

SiSyncGetScaleOverall

SpwReturnValue SiSyncGetScaleOverall ( SiHdl hdl, SPWfloat32 *pv )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

pv 

(w/o) 

the current overall scale factor 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument 


Example
SiSyncGetScaleOverall ( m_hdl, &overallScaleFactor );

Description
SiSyncGetScaleOverall retrieves the current overall scale factor used by the driver.  This is as shown on a slider in the driver's GUI.

 

SiSyncSetScaleOverall

SpwReturnValue SiSyncSetScaleOverall ( SiHdl hdl, SPWfloat32 v )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

v 

(r/o) 

the requested new overall scale factor 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument 


Example
SiSyncSetScaleOverall ( m_hdl, overallScaleFactor *= 2.0f );

Description
SiSyncSetScaleOverall requests a new scale factor for the driver's overall scale factor slider.  If the slider can not accommodate the new setting (because it is outside the range of the slider, the driver will send an asynchronous SetScaleOverall sync packet to the application with the closest setting it could achieve.

SiSyncInvokeAbsoluteFunction

SpwReturnValue SiSyncInvokeAbsoluteFunction ( SiHdl hdl, SiSyncAbsFunctionNumber i )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

i 

(r/o) 

the absolute function index to invoke 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

invalid absolute function index 


Example
SiSyncInvokeAbsoluteFunction ( m_hdl, SI_SYNC_FUNCTION_3DX_HELP );

Description
SiInvokeAbsoluteFunction immediately causes one of the absolute (guaranteed to be there) function to be invoked.  Certain functions can always be invoked regardless of their listing in a config file.  These are termed absolute functions.  The functions numbers can be listed via SiSyncGetFunction but are hard-coded, guaranteed to never change, so they can also be invoked using the constants in siSync.h.

 

SiSyncSetButtonState

SpwReturnValue SiSyncSetButtonState ( SiHdl hdl, SPWuint32 buttonNumber, SiSyncButtonState state )

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 

buttonNumber 

(r/o) 

the button number to change (1-n) 

state 

(r/o) 

the new state of the button 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 

SI_BAD_VALUE 

bad argument 


Example
SiSyncSetButtonState ( m_hdl, buttonNumber, SI_SYNC_BUTTON_STATE_OFF );

Description
SiSyncSetButtonState changes the state (on / off / disabled) of a button.  This only effects buttons that are assigned to be passthru events (function 0), not buttons assigned to driver functions.  If the new state is OFF, the button is put into reverse video.

 

SiSyncSuspendFileWriting

enum SpwRetVal SiSyncSuspendFileWriting(SiHdl hdl)

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 


Example
SiSyncSuspendFileWriting ( m_hdl );

Description
This function sends a sync command to the driver to suspend profile file writing.
File writing to disk takes a relatively long time, and it causes extra updates that are redundant if, for example, the client is updating a whole list of buttons.
The client can use this function to suspend the file updates until it is all done.
In the suspended state, the driver just updates in memory data structures.
Once the app is done with its big sequence of updates, it can call SiSyncResumeFileWriting to have all the pending (and subsequent) updates written to disk.
Requires 3DxWare 10 or newer.

 

SiSyncResumeFileWriting

enum SpwRetVal SiSyncResumeFileWriting(SiHdl hdl)

hdl 

(r/o) 

the 3DxWare input device handle returned by SiOpen or SiOpenPort 


Return Value

SPW_NO_ERROR 

no error 

SI_BAD_HANDLE 

invalid handle 


Example
SiSyncResumeFileWriting ( m_hdl );

Description
This function resumes profile file writing that was suspended by a paired call to SiSyncSuspendFileWriting.
Requires 3DxWare 10 or newer.
